summary: NATO delegates visited SaxaVord Spaceport and its German launch partner RFA, with test flights anticipated later this year from the UK's sole fully-licensed vertical launch site[cite: 1].
RFA published a blog post on the role of space in European security and defense and how the RFA ONE launch vehicle can enhance resilience[cite: 2, 4].
RFA announced a partnership with local coffee roastery Bohnenschmiede to launch an official RFA-branded coffee[cite: 8].
The Deputy Minister President of Bavaria and Bavarian Minister of Economic Affairs visited RFA's headquarters in Augsburg[cite: 10].
RFA congratulates its competitor, Isar Aerospace, on the successful first test flight of their Spectrum launch vehicle from Andøya Spaceport[cite: 13, 15].
RFA extends its best wishes to competitor Isar Aerospace for their Spectrum rocket launch campaign[cite: 17, 19].
RFA shared a quote from General Traut, Head of the German Space Command, emphasizing the security importance of sovereign launch capabilities developed by German and UK companies[cite: 21].
RFA's 2024 year-in-review highlights successful first stage and Redshift OTV hot fires, securing €11.8M in ESA funding, and plans for a first test flight[cite: 25, 27, 30].
Space influencer Tim Dodd, the Everyday Astronaut, visited RFA's German headquarters for a behind-the-scenes tour and interview[cite: 31, 32].
RFA highlights initial joint activities in Scotland with its customer Cirium 5, whose payload will be on TestFlight1 aboard the Redshift OTV[cite: 34, 35].
As part of its #RFAdvent series, RFA showcases the RFA ONE's payload fairing, which was prepared at RFA Portugal and is ready for shipping[cite: 37].
RFA's #RFAdvent reveals the trajectory for Test Flight 1 passes behind the Muckle Flugga lighthouse in the Shetlands[cite: 38].
RFA's #RFAdvent series features its Augsburg workshop, showcasing the first stage integration and the mounting of nine Helix engines on the thrust frame[cite: 42, 43].
RFA launched a "Meet the Team" video series, starting with a propulsion engineer explaining the Helix engine[cite: 45].
RFA's CEO announces receiving the official launch license for the first test flight and discusses European space flight in an interview with CNBC[cite: 47, 49, 50].

ESA's Director General congratulates RFA for receiving its Spaceflight Operator Licence from the UK Civil Aviation Authority for an RFA ONE test flight from SaxaVord Spaceport in 2025[cite: 53, 56, 57].

RFA announces it has received all three key regulatory authorizations, including the first-ever launch license outside ESA's Kourou site, for its RFA ONE test flight in 2025 from SaxaVord Spaceport[cite: 58, 64].
RFA, with Hylmpulse, Latitude, MaiaSpace, Orbex, and The Exploration Company, sent a joint position paper to ESA outlining priorities for the European Launcher Challenge[cite: 65, 67].
RFA released a blog post detailing the RFA ONE's engineering, highlighting its stainless steel design, Helix staged-combustion engine, and focus on cost-efficiency and reusability[cite: 69].
Reacting to a SpaceX achievement, RFA states that Europe has 'lost touch' and calls for state anchor customers and substantial investment to remain competitive[cite: 70, 71, 74].

RFA's CCO announces his participation in a panel at the MSC Space Night 2025 to discuss the critical need for independent European access to space and responsive launch capabilities led by Germany[cite: 83, 85, 87, 90].
RFA's co-founder and COO, Dr. Stefan Brieschenk, is scheduled for a live interview with NASASpaceflight LLC to discuss rockets and staged-combustion engines[cite: 94].

RFA successfully installed all nine Helix engines on the RFA ONE first stage at SaxaVord Spaceport, marking a first for a European rocket, as preparations for the next hot fire test advance[cite: 99, 100].
RFA provides a downloadable wallpaper featuring a view of its rocket[cite: 103].
RFA is recruiting for an experienced Avionics Production Manager to serve as a Group Lead, requiring at least 5 years of production experience[cite: 105, 108].

RFA's COO, Dr. Stefan Brieschenk, provides a transparent update on a first stage (S1) test anomaly that resulted in the loss of the stage, highlighting the significant amount of data collected[cite: 115, 119].

In its #ASKRFA series, RFA explains that its Fenix engine, which powers the Redshift Orbital Transfer Vehicle (OTV), is capable of multiple re-ignitions for flexible in-orbit satellite delivery[cite: 120, 122].

RFA successfully completed a full-duration hot fire of its Redshift OTV third stage, qualifying it for flight after a test including a nearly 600s burn, a 40-minute coasting simulation, and a 30s circularization burn[cite: 124, 125].

RFA's COO, Dr. Stefan Brieschenk, provides a personal and transparent account of a first-stage hot-fire test failure that led to the loss of the stage, with the preliminary root cause identified as an oxygen-fire in a turbopump[cite: 130, 146].
RFA's CCO, Jörn Spurmann, addresses the loss of the first stage during a hot fire test, expressing confidence in the team's resilience to overcome the setback[cite: 179, 185].
This post contains no analyzable content.
RFA released the full, raw video footage of its stage one hot fire test from start to finish[cite: 191].
In celebration of International Women's Day 2025, RFA promotes its inclusive culture and directs interested individuals to its careers page[cite: 193, 195, 196].
RFA invites the public for an exclusive behind-the-scenes tour in March to see how one of Europe's leading privately developed rockets is built.
RFA issues a public appeal for citizens to participate in the upcoming federal elections in Germany[cite: 197, 198].
RFA's CCO Jörn Spurmann and Head of Acquisition & Delivery Dr. Ibrahim Ata are attending the 17th European Space Conference in Brussels on January 28-29, 2025.

RFA announces it is the first European company to receive a Spaceflight Operator Licence from the UK Civil Aviation Authority for orbital launches, covering the RFA ONE test flight from SaxaVord Spaceport in 2025[cite: 202, 203, 204].
RFA extends New Year's wishes to its community and designates 2025 as the year of its first test flight[cite: 208, 211].
As part of its #RFAdvent series, RFA wishes a Merry Christmas from its teams in Germany, Sweden, Scotland, and Portugal, looking forward to its journey in 2025[cite: 213, 215].

RFA's #RFAdvent highlights the successful qualification test of its Redshift OTV, which included a nearly 600s burn, a 40-minute coasting simulation, and a 30s circularization burn powered by the re-ignitable Fenix engine[cite: 216, 217].
Day 20 of RFA's #RFAdvent features the ~20m high first stage (S1002) standing on the launch stool at SaxaVord Spaceport[cite: 219, 220].
RFA's #RFAdvent post throws back to the construction of its test stand in Sweden over four years ago, highlighting its low-cost philosophy using shipping containers as a blast wall[cite: 222].
On day 17 of its #RFAdvent, RFA honors its team for achieving two multi-engine hotfires with the first stage this year[cite: 223].

Day 16 of RFA's #RFAdvent shows final preparations on the Redshift OTV, the third stage designed to deploy multiple satellites into different orbits and potentially remove space debris in the future[cite: 224, 225, 226].
This #RFAdvent post highlights the scenic landscapes and Northern Lights near RFA's facilities.
Day 14 of #RFAdvent marks the milestone of lifting the first stage onto the launchpad for the first time[cite: 227].
Day 13 of #RFAdvent features a team picture from RFA Portugal, where the payload fairing and main structures for the Redshift OTV are manufactured from automotive-grade carbon fiber[cite: 228, 230].
Day 12 of #RFAdvent notes that the flight-qualified second and third stages (Redshift OTV) are awaiting a new first stage for Test Flight 1[cite: 234].
On Day 10 of #RFAdvent, RFA highlights its pragmatic engineering by explaining how it qualified its turbopump using a retrofitted, used helicopter engine[cite: 235, 236].
This #RFAdvent post spotlights the main test site near Kiruna, Sweden, where Helix engines are tested and where the integrated second stage hot fire test occurred in May 2023[cite: 239, 240].
In this humorous #RFAdvent Day 6 post, RFA playfully offers Santa an extra 500,000 horsepower.
#RFAdvent Day 5 looks back to December 2022, when the launch stool, built by the maritime industry for durability, was being installed at SaxaVord Spaceport[cite: 241, 242].
Day 4 of the #RFAdvent Countdown features an analogue photo of the RFA team, blending old-school photography with innovative rocket technology[cite: 244, 245].
Day 3 of #RFAdvent shows the retrofitting of the remaining Helix engines onto the first stage using a working platform and crane inside the launch stool[cite: 248, 249].
Day 2 of the #RFAdvent calendar shows a sunrise over the SaxaVord Spaceport launch site, with a message of resilience following the loss of the S1002 stage[cite: 251, 252].
Day 1 of #RFAdvent gives a look inside an RFA ONE tank, revealing the 1.2 mm thick stainless steel construction chosen for its cost-effectiveness and suitability for reuse[cite: 254].
RFA announces the start of its #RFAdvent calendar, promising daily behind-the-scenes content[cite: 255].
RFA's CCO is participating in a panel discussion at the SpaceTech Expo on 'Enabling the Consolidation of the Micro-Launch Services Market'[cite: 257].
RFA reports an anomaly during a first stage hot fire test at SaxaVord Spaceport, resulting in the loss of the stage but no injuries or damage to the launch pad[cite: 260, 261].
RFA introduces Karl, its lead structural engineer, in a 'Meet the Team' post, highlighting the company's focus on balancing high efficiency with low cost[cite: 267].
RFA is hiring an RF Systems Engineer in Augsburg to develop telemetry and flight termination systems, requiring 8+ years of experience[cite: 271, 274].

RFA has completed its second stage acceptance campaign, demonstrating autonomous O/F ratio adjustment and achieving just 1% unburnt propellant, making the stage ready for the first test flight[cite: 278, 279, 280].
RFA successfully completed the final separation test of its payload fairing in Portugal, which is now on its way to SaxaVord Spaceport[cite: 281, 283].
In its #MeetTheTeam series, RFA features Technical Project Manager Erika McDowell, who manages propulsion and Redshift OTV activities[cite: 284, 286].
RFA announces 200kg of available payload capacity for its second test flight, offering a customized transport service to a polar orbit for next year[cite: 290, 291].
RFA launches a new Q&A series, #ASKRFA, inviting the community to ask questions about the company's technology and mission[cite: 293, 294, 295].
RFA congratulates the European Space Agency and the European space industry on the successful first launch of Ariane 6[cite: 297].

RFA provides a technical update on its second stage, explaining the differences between the sea-level Helix and vacuum HelixVAC engines, particularly the nozzle size and spin-start systems[cite: 298, 299, 303, 306, 307].
RFA publishes a new blog post detailing its launch site at SaxaVord, covering the design, construction, systems, and safety considerations[cite: 309].
RFA announces the attendance of its CCO, Head of Acquisition and Delivery, and Institutional Sales Manager at the Space Transportation Ecosystem Conference in Munich[cite: 313].
The #MeetTheTeam series introduces Llewelyn, a Mechanical Design Engineer responsible for designing assembly equipment, including a system that rotates the entire rocket[cite: 322, 323].
RFA's CCO is speaking on the "What market for mini-launchers?" panel at the Paris Air Forum 2024[cite: 326, 327].
RFA's CCO is participating in the panel discussion '2024 - A fateful year for Europe's access to space' at the ILA Berlin Air Show[cite: 329].

RFA reports a successful milestone with two quick-succession hot fires of its Fenix engine for the Redshift OTV, totaling 80 seconds of burn time, demonstrating hardware resilience for multiple ignitions[cite: 331].
